The number of active Mastodon users — those who've logged in in the last 30 days — has fallen to 1.8 million from a high of 2.6 million. This reflects the fact that while there's a wave of new users after each Musk tantrum, the majority aren't sticking around. Even the 1.8M figure is inflated by new accounts, so I expect a further drop.

Still, the number of active users is over 4 times what it used to be before the Twitter takeover.

Source: https://api.joinmastodon.org/statistics (and Wayback machine).

title: Muzzled by DeSantis, Critical Race Theory Professors Cancel Courses or Modify Their Teaching

last_post.content:
Muzzled by DeSantis, Critical Race Theory Professors Cancel Courses or Modify Their Teaching
--
It’s easy to dismiss the conservative crusade against #CRT as political theater without real consequences. But most colleges & universities offer social science and humanities courses that address racial inequality and systemic racism, and the anti-CRT laws are already having repercussions for people who teach or take these classes in red states.

#race #education #Florida

https://www.propublica.org/article/desantis-critical-race-theory-florida-college-professors?utm_medium=social&utm_source=mastodon&utm_campaign=mastodon-post

- Looking for remote, but can commute (Minneapolis/St. Paul, MN, USA)
- I'm a trans woman, so clear acceptance/queer coworkers are a huge plus

Entry level would be best, I don't have enough work experience for most places to look at me mid-level. DM for a resume or any questions, take a look at my site for some examples of things I do!
https://werefox.cafe :aliceheartblack:

It's time to unbundle science. I put in a lot of work writing blog posts. This last one (https://xcorr.net/2023/01/01/2022-in-review-neuroai-comes-of-age/) was 100+ hours in the making.

I could put in a few extra hours, reformat and submit to a preprint server to get citations. But it feels silly: lock up the research behind a pdf that's not mobile accessible, remove the convenient placement of the links for a bibliography, strip all the screenshots from the papers I link to... maybe I'd even need to change the voice to a mimic serious formal science and I don't want that.

So I'm experimental with unbundling science by making some of the artifacts citable. I released the figure I generated for this blog post on figshare, with a citable DOI. Let me know if you think this is useful. https://figshare.com/articles/figure/Typology_of_neuroAI/21818403

title: Leaked Jan. 6 Twitter Report Reveals Internal Chaos Over Insurrection

last_post.content:
Leaked Jan. 6 Committee Report Exposes Twitter’s Post-Insurrection Chaos

Company employees lashed out at leadership over an ad hoc content moderation policy that they blamed for enabling Donald Trump's insurrection

Both committee staff and former employees who gave depositions singled out former Twitter Vice President for Trust & Safety Del Harvey as an obstacle to tougher enforcement against election-related extremism in the run-up to the insurrection. Harvey, the 120-page summary concludes, “personally obstructed” the creation of a coded incitement to violence policy drafted by Twitter Safety employees in the months before the insurrection. https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-news/jan6-twitter-trump-elon-musk-capitol-attack-1234655022/

I agree with this sentiment.
Punchy!

https://startafuckingblog.com/

1/n) I've been experimenting with #GPT3, having it write summaries for @icymi_law's digest. See https://icymilaw.org

Knowing #LLM s are bullshitters (producing things that sound good w/o a need for a factual basis) I've been keeping it on a short leash, providing a quick glance at content before it went out, & yesterday I caught a doozy before press.

The model hallucinated a bill imposing the death penalty for abortion providers based on this @chrisgeidner article: https://www.lawdork.com/p/missouri-is-scheduled-to-execute

title: 2022: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics

last_post.content:
If you're even passingly interested in #dataviz / etc, take a few to compare these two offerings:

(1) The NYT's "2022: The Year in Visual Stories and Graphics" https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/12/28/us/2022-year-in-graphics.html

(2) "Tableau Public’s Viz Wrap: Interesting Data Visualizations from 2022" https://www.tableau.com/blog/tableau-public-viz-wrap-interesting-data-visualizations-2022

Even allowing for the fact that two projects are different in key ways — institutional capacity and context foremost among them — what strikes me is how flat, conventional, and superficially decorative the Tableau offerings are.

From the mid-'90s, when dataviz became more (yes) a pop phenomenon, it's struggled with how deeply its aesthetics are defined by the software tools designers relied on. They should have struggled *against* that, imo. But doing so would require a deeper understanding of the field's evolution over the last century than the obsessive recitation of names like Playfair and Minard (and, more recently, Nightingale and Dubois). The fixation on those historical figures is a classic bourgie move: using "classical" figures to signal tradition and legitimacy. (Datavizzies are way overdue for a new year's resolution to move on from that classic-rock stuff.)

I can be bitterly critical of the NYT, but its commitment to experimenting with journalistic form and content around dataviz is unparalleled. The fact that one institution could trot out its own work over just one year and *blow away* a more inwardly oriented dataviz roster says a lot.

(2) "Tableau Public’s Viz Wrap: Interesting Data Visualizations from 2022" https://www.tableau.com/blog/tableau-public-viz-wrap-interesting-data-visualizations-2022

Fact 5: Support for #Brexit collapsed quickly after the #EUReferendum.

The protest vote that drove #Brexit (which is the vote that matters) collapsed in a very predictable fashion almost immediately after the #EUReferendum

I wrote a paper about this: Who is NOT voting for #Brexit anymore...

https://tinyurl.com/45bz4tz8

The biggest declines in #Brexit support were coming from the places where the #ProtestVote was highest... not surprisingly.

Here is a short write up
https://ukandeu.ac.uk/is-the-uk-having-a-rethink-on-brexit/

title: How has the Universe changed since last year?

last_post.content:
How has the Universe changed since last year?

The Sun is lighter; the Earth's orbit and rotational period have changed; the Moon is farther away; more galaxies are visible; but fewer stars are reachable.

Profound cosmic changes occur with each new year!
https://bigthink.com/starts-with-a-bang/universe-changed-year/

.@Riedl spotted this new sentence in the #ICML ethics section saying that papers can't include text generated from LLMs.

I guess I don't really even know what "generated" means, but I would find it super strange if we can't use a LLM to turn bullets into prose that we then edit…, especially since ppl seem much more ok with copilot producing code that we then edit?

I hope #acmchi and others find a more human-centered way to address this (if it needs addressing at all).

https://icml.cc/Conferences/2023/CallForPapers

Hi, I've just moved over to hcommons.social, so here's an #introduction. I work (and make things) at the nexus of digital culture, politics and technology. I'm Prof of Media at Coventry University, UK, where I direct the Centre for Postdigital Cultures. I research non-liberal & non-humanist forms of collaboration and knowledge commons, as well as questions of class, elitism & digital capitalism. I’ve been involved for a while in creating ‘norm-critical’ collaborative research contexts. In 1999 I started an online journal Culture Machine http://www.culturemachine.net/. In 2006 I co-founded the open access publishing house Open Humanities Press. OHP was then a founder member of the Radical Open Access Collective http://radicaloa.disruptivemedia.org.uk/. My books include A Stubborn Fury: How Writing Works In Elitist Britain (OHP, 2021) http://www.openhumanitiespress.org/books/titles/a-stubborn-fury/, Pirate Philosophy (MIT Press, 2016) https://mitpress.mit.edu/9780262034401/pirate-philosophy/, and The Uberfication of the University (Minnesota UP, 2016) https://manifold.umn.edu/projects/the-uberfication-of-the-university.

My books include A Stubborn Fury: How Writing Works In Elitist Britain (OHP, 2021) http://www.openhumanitiespress.org/books/titles/a-stubborn-fury/, Pirate Philosophy (MIT Press, 2016) https://mitpress.mit.edu/9780262034401/pirate-philosophy/, and The Uberfication of the University (Minnesota UP, 2016) https://manifold.umn.edu/projects/the-uberfication-of-the-university.

Hi, I've just moved over to hcommons.social, so here's an #introduction. I work (and make things) at the nexus of digital culture, politics and technology. I'm Prof of Media at Coventry University, UK, where I direct the Centre for Postdigital Cultures. I research non-liberal & non-humanist forms of collaboration and knowledge commons, as well as questions of class, elitism & digital capitalism. I’ve been involved for a while in creating ‘norm-critical’ collaborative research contexts. In 1999 I started an online journal Culture Machine http://www.culturemachine.net/. In 2006 I co-founded the open access publishing house Open Humanities Press. OHP was then a founder member of the Radical Open Access Collective http://radicaloa.disruptivemedia.org.uk/. My books include A Stubborn Fury: How Writing Works In Elitist Britain (OHP, 2021) http://www.openhumanitiespress.org/books/titles/a-stubborn-fury/, Pirate Philosophy (MIT Press, 2016) https://mitpress.mit.edu/9780262034401/pirate-philosophy/, and The Uberfication of the University (Minnesota UP, 2016) https://manifold.umn.edu/projects/the-uberfication-of-the-university.

title: Bike lanes are a sound public health investment

last_post.content:
Using Quality-Adjusted Life Years as a metric, the cost for society to buy 1 additional year of life at full health is as follows:
Vaccines $0.1K
Bike lanes: $1K
Medicaid $67K
Dialysis $129K
Source: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-costbenefit-bike-lanes-idUSKCN11Z23A #publichealth #BikeTooter #vaccines #healthcare #sdoh #walkability #cycling

title: De La Soul's catalog coming to streaming services for the first time

last_post.content: This is massive news. I've long believed that #DeLaSoul's crucial role in American musical history has been diminished by their absence from streaming services due in part to the #copyright clearance burden of their sample-heavy sound on the first few albums. I hope they get (re)discovered by Gen Z thanks to this! https://consequence.net/2023/01/de-la-soul-catalog-streaming-services/

title: Explanation and reproducibility in data-driven science (new course) | Statistical Modeling, Causal Inference, and Social Science

last_post.content:
Reading Hullman's syllabus for "Explanation and Reproducibility in Data-Driven Science" made me actually wish I was in the business of academia once again https://statmodeling.stat.columbia.edu/2023/01/03/explanation-and-reproducibility-in-data-driven-science-new-course/

This course looks like an instant classic.

Is there anything different about the #FAIR principles for research software (#FAIR4RS, https://doi.org/10.15497/RDA00068) when working in an #HPC context?

I think the answer is no for findability and accessibility, but I'm less sure if this is true for interoperability and reusability.

title: JPSO used facial recognition technology to arrest a man. The tech was wrong.

last_post.content:
Another Black man falsely accused of a crime and arrested because of a bad facial recognition search. Fourth or so we know about; probably many more we don't. Arrested while driving to a family Thanksgiving and kept in jail for 7 days, even though he'd never been in the same state as the crime scene

https://www.nola.com/news/crime_police/jpso-used-facial-recognition-to-arrest-a-man-it-was-wrong/article_0818361a-8886-11ed-8119-93b98ecccc8d.html

title: Lattice-based cryptography: The tricky math of dots

last_post.content:
Lattices are simple looking patterns of dots. But lattice problems are really hard. They could be the basis for post-quantum cryptography.

More details in a new video
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QDdOoYdb748

title: AEA Web - American Economic Journal: Applied Economics - 5(3):63 - Abstract

last_post.content:
Does anyone know of a paper that constructs an h-index variant that adjusts for the productivity of coauthors?

Glenn Ellison, in his paper, adjusts for # of coauthors, but not their fixed effect/citation impact without you

https://pubs.aeaweb.org/doi/pdfplus/10.1257/app.5.3.63

title: Bankruptcy judge rules that Earn account assets belong to Celsius

last_post.content:
“Not your keys, not your coins” now has legal precedent. The judge in Celsius’ bankruptcy hearing ruled that the deposits in yield-bearing Earn accounts belong to Celsius, not the individual holders of those accounts.

Won’t this cause a run on exchanges?

https://www.axios.com/2023/01/04/celsius-bankruptcy-earn-accounts

"This modest box is one of the first electronic voting machines in the history of the Congress. Electronic voting was introduced in the House in 1973. Members voted by inserting their voting card into the slot and pressing the appropriate button to indicate 'yea,' 'nay,' or 'present.' The stations also have an 'open' indicator, which is lit when a vote is in progress and the system is ready to accept votes."² #govtech (I never found any info on this IC chip.)

² https://history.house.gov/Collection/Detail/42898
